title: Passengers ordered to stop swearing on holiday flight from Glasgow to Ibiza
text:
9
View
comments
A video has emerged of rowdy passengers raving on board a Glasgow to Ibiza flight, forcing cabin crew to plead with the holidaymakers not to swear in front of children on board.
The flight was en route to the party island when those on board burst into song, belting out club classic 'Look Right Through' by Storm Queen.
One of the passengers used a speaker or handheld device to blast the song so everyone on board could hear it, and soon a host of people turn the flight into their own personal party.
Passengers rave on flight to Ibiza for rowdy behaviour Passengers on board the Ibiza-bound flight started to rave along to a club classic
This led to a flight attendant to say over the tannoy system: 'Ladies and gentlemen, please remain quiet. There are travellers on board with young children. Please do not swear. Thank you.'
But it appears many of those on board were keen to get the party started even before they had set foot in the haven for raving, that hosts clubs such as Amnesia, Space and Pacha.
And of course phones were at the ready to record the impromptu rave.

Opinion appears to be split as to whether the behaviour was inappropriate, judging by comments on the social-networking website.
A user named Robert Quote: : 'Scumbag behaviour... what about the other passengers?'
Ryan Scott added: 'Ban kids from Ibiza flights!'
The actions prompted the cabin crew to warn those on board to stay quiet and not to swear
Emma Kivell was similarly unimpressed with the actions on board, writing: 'Put everyone's safety at risk cos they think it's funny.'
And there was no doubt which side of the fence Toni Everson was on, adding: 'One thing to go on holiday and have a laugh, but there's families on the flight you can clearly hear the flight attendants trying to control the crowd. Just rude, immature idiots with no manners.'
However, some saw the funny side of a mass chorus, despite the cabin crew resorting to special announcements to tone down the noise.
Trudy Gourlay, who was apparently on the flight, writes: 'I loved the Ibiza flight. Kept me amused the whole way. It's only banter.'
And Adam Murray said: 'On the way out this is how it should be.'
